_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary



Background Data



In accordance with title 40 of the code of Federal Regulations chapter 68 (40 CFR 68) promulgated by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), Sweet Street Desserts (SSD) - Greenville, SC submits this Risk Management Plan (RMP) for operations at their Greenville, SC facility.  Sweet Street Desserts - Greenville, SC facility makes pastries.  The major processes at the Greenville facility include flour handling and storage, ingredient mixing, pastry baking, freezing and product packaging and distribution.  Raw materials are delivered to this facility by trucks.  



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Sweet Street Desserts - Greenville, SC is committed to protecting the health of its employees the surrounding community, and the environment; therefore it is Sweet Street Desserts - Greenville, SC policy to manage a safe and healthy workplace, protect the environment, and maintain compliance with safety, health, and environmental regulations:  40 CFR 68 as well as occupational Safety and Health Organization (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations promulgated as Title 29 of the Code of Federal Regulations Chapter 1910, Section 119 (29 CFR 1910.119), and OSHA's Hazardous Operations and Emergency Response Regulation (29 CFR 1910.120).



Stationary Source and Regulated Substances 



Sweet Street Desserts - Greenville, SC uses anhydrous ammonia (a 112(r) regulated substance) as a refrigerant to manufacture and store product within the required range of operating temperatures.  Anhydrous ammonia is an industry-standard refrigerant for food processing plants.  Sweet Street Desserts - Greenville, SC refrigeration system consists of receivers, compressors, evaporators, water chiller, condensers, and piping in an engineered closed loop system.



Accidental Release Prevention Program



Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration system is designed and constructed in accordance with South Carolin

a 2012 IMC, IFC, IBC Codes and ANSI/IIAR 2-2008 Standards for Equipment, Design and Installation of Ammonia Mechanical Refrigeration systems.  To prevent and mitigate accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia, Sweet Street Desserts - Greenville, SC has implemented several precautionary measures, such as process/equipment controls, standard operation procedures, preventative maintenance programs, employee training and audit programs



Sweet Street Desserts- Greenville, SC maintains a no odor policy.  The no odor policy instructs employees that detect an ammonia odor to call the Refrigeration Technicians who must respond immediately to the call to address the situation.



Sweet Street Desserts- Greenville, SC has implemented and is in compliance with OSHAs PSM regulations and as such, has evaluated and engineered for anhydrous ammonia releases.  Some of the controls installed to prevent catastrophic releases of ammonia are process equipment (vents, pressure relief valves, backup pumps, and manual shutoffs) and automated controls (automatic shut-offs, ammonia leak detection systems, and electrical distribution system grounding).  



Sweet Street Desserts - Greenville, SC has developed Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) for all employees and contractors that have contact with the ammonia refrigeration system that incorporate safety measures into the procedures.  These safety procedures were developed by refrigeration system operators and are reviewed on an annual basis by means of an SOP review session.  Process safety information for the refrigeration system is reviewed during these annual meetings as well.  Sweet Street Desserts- Greenville, SC encourages employee participation in development of the control measure used at the plant by means of the annual procedures review.  Any changes to the operating procedures are communicated to affected employees following written management of change procedures established by Sweet Street Desserts- Greenville, SC.



Sweet S

treet Desserts- Greenville, SC understands that maintaining the refrigeration system in good working order is essential to preventing accidental releases; therefore Sweet Street Desserts- Greenville, SC has implemented a preventative maintenance (PM) program.  The preventative maintenance program is scheduled, documented and managed to ensure that regular maintenance occurs on the refrigeration system.  Also, to ensure the mechanical integrity of critical refrigeration system components, auditing is conducted every 5 years by a certified refrigeration contractor.



To ensure that Sweet Street Desserts- Greenville, SC control measure are effective in maintaining the safe operation of the plant, regularly scheduled audits are performed on the ammonia refrigeration system.



In accordance with the PSM program, Sweet Street Desserts- Greenville, SC conducts detailed PSM compliance audits every three years that incorporate review of process safety information, process hazard analysis operating procedures, training programs, system mechanical integrity, management of change, pre-start up review procedures, compliance audit procedures, and contractor safety procedures.  In addition, Sweet Street Desserts-Greenville, SC is subject to auditing by the local fire department, OSHA and the Environmental Protection Agency.



Five-Year Accident History



 Sweet Street Desserts- Greenville, SC Will start operations first quarter 2015



Emergency Response Program



Sweet Street Desserts- Greenville, SC has developed a comprehensive emergency response program designed to protect both employees and the community in the event of a release.  This program is fully described in a document entitled Emergency Response Plan (ERP) in order to facilitate response efforts in the event of off-site releases of anhydrous ammonia.  Included in the ERP are measures to be taken internally the Sweet Street Desserts- Greenville, SC as well as measure to be taken by off-site response agencies.

Sweet Street Desserts - Greenville, SC has trained on-site personnel to respond to accidental releases of regulated substances.  These personnel are trained in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.120, OSHAs Hazardous Operations and Emergency Response regulations according to their duties and function.  These personnel receive initial training and annual update training thereafter.  Sweet Street Desserts- Greenville, SC stages mock release incidents annually to test the skills of the HazMat team, determine the teams readiness, and identify areas of improvement.



To assure that the local governmental response agencies are familiar with Sweet Street Desserts- Greenville, SC emergency response procedures, Sweet Street Desserts- Greenville, SC has submitted copies of the ERP for review and approval by the local agencies.  The following local agencies have reviewed Sweet Street Desserts Greenville, SC ERP



Greenville County Office of Emergency Management (LEPC)



To pre-plan for an anhydrous ammonia release with off-site effects, Sweet Street Desserts- Greenville, SC ERP includes procedures/equipment to mitigate the release, procedures to inform local response agencies, evacuation procedures, and procedures for public communication.



In the event of an anhydrous ammonia release with off-site effects, the general public will be warned by the Local Emergency Planning committee (LEPC) according to the facility off-site plan which is updated on an annual basis by the LEPC. Any significant changes to the ERP will communicated to the agencies listed above.



Continuous Efforts to Improve Safety



The process will be subjected to regular process hazard analyses reviews for the purpose of identifying and implementing potential improvements.  Facility and Corporate personnel will also periodically review all potential opportunities to improve the safety of our personnel, the surrounding community, and the ammonia refrigeration process.
